abstract.text: A render target that serves as the output destination for pixels generated by a render pass.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object to configure an individual render target of a framebuffer. Each
object specifies one texture that a graphics rendering pass can write into.
object creates a default set of attachment objects. For each attachment that you intend to use as a render target, retrieve the
object from the render pass descriptor and configure its properties for use during this rendering pass.
properties specify the mipmap level, slice, and depth plane (for 3D textures) of the texture, respectively.
properties specify actions to perform at the start and end of a rendering pass for the attachment, respectively. For example, if you set the
, then the contents of the texture fill with a value for the type of attachment at the start of the rendering pass.
subclasses for color, depth, and stencil attachments. Each subclass provides additional properties to configure for that kind of attachment. The table below provides the list of subclasses.
To perform multisampled antialiased rendering, you use two textures. Attach to the
texture, and a 2D or cube texture to the

property. When a rendering command executes, it renders to the multisample texture. At the end of the render pass, the GPU resolves the contents of the multisample texture and writes the results into the resolve texture. The
properties specify where the resolved image is written to. The attachment’s
property determines what happens to the multisample texture after the GPU resolves its data.

abstract.text: Render advanced 3D graphics and compute data in parallel with graphics processors.
An RGBA value used for a color pixel.
The GPU writes a value to every pixel in the attachment at the start of the render pass.
Filtering options for controlling an MSAA depth resolve operation.
Constants used to control the multisample stencil resolve operation.
A render target that serves as the output destination for pixels generated by a render pass.
The depth plane of the texture used for rendering to the attachment.
The mipmap level of the texture used for rendering to the attachment.
The action performed by this attachment at the start of a rendering pass for a render command encoder.
The depth plane of the texture used for the multisample resolve action.
The mipmap level of the texture used for the multisample resolve action.
The slice of the texture used for the multisample resolve action.
The destination texture used when resolving multisampled texture data into single sample values.
The slice of the texture used for rendering to the attachment.
The action performed by this attachment at the end of a rendering pass for a render command encoder.
The options that modify the store action performed by this attachment.
The texture object associated with this attachment.
A color render target that serves as the output destination for color pixels generated by a render pass.
An array of render pass color attachment descriptor objects.
A depth render target that serves as the output destination for depth pixels generated by a render pass.
A group of render targets that hold the results of a render pass.
A description of where to store GPU counter information at the start and end of a render pass.
An array of sample buffer attachments for a render pass.
A stencil render target that serves as the output destination for stencil pixels generated by a render pass.
A two-dimensional texture image that uses more than one sample for each pixel.
An array of color attachment descriptors for the tile render pipeline.
Select an appropriate storage mode for your textures and buffers on Apple GPUs.

doc://com.apple.metal/documentation/Meta.title: Choosing a Resource Storage Mode for Apple GPUs

abstract.text: Set actions that define how a render pass loads and stores a render target.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
